content: The Act is titled the "Unrecognized Southeast Alaska Native Communities Recognition and Compensation Act" and its purpose is outlined in the findings section. Congress enacted the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act in 1971 to recognize and settle the aboriginal claims of Alaska Natives to land they used for traditional purposes. The Act awarded $1 billion and 44 million acres of land to Alaska Natives, who were enrolled in 1 of 13 Regional Corporations. Village or Urban Corporations established under the Act received cash and surface rights to the settlement land. The Act awarded cash and surface rights to settlement land to Village or Urban Corporations. Southeastern Alaska communities like Haines, Ketchikan, Petersburg, Tenakee, and Wrangell, despite comprising over 20% of the shareholders of the Regional Corporation for Southeast Alaska, are not eligible under the Act. The Act awarded cash and surface rights to settlement land to Village or Urban Corporations in Southeastern Alaska communities. Despite comprising over 20% of the shareholders of the Regional Corporation for Southeast Alaska, communities like Haines, Ketchikan, Petersburg, Tenakee, and Wrangell have been seeking eligibility for over 3 decades. In 1993, Congress directed the Secretary of the Interior to prepare a report examining the reasons for their denial of eligibility. The report published in February 1994 indicated that these communities are similar to others eligible to form Village or Urban Corporations and receive land and benefits under the Act. The Act awarded cash and surface rights to settlement land to Village or Urban Corporations in Southeastern Alaska communities. Despite comprising over 20% of the shareholders of the Regional Corporation for Southeast Alaska, communities like Haines, Ketchikan, Petersburg, Tenakee, and Wrangell have been seeking eligibility for over 3 decades. In 1993, Congress directed the Secretary of the Interior to prepare a report examining the reasons for their denial of eligibility. The report published in February 1994 indicated that these communities are similar to others eligible to form Village or Urban Corporations and receive land and benefits under the Act. The omissions in the Act regarding Native Alaskan communities are not clearly explained in any provision or legislative history. The purpose of this Act is to address the exclusion of Alaska Natives in five communities from eligibility for benefits under the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act. It authorizes the formation of Urban Corporations for Haines, Ketchikan, Petersburg, Tenakee, and Wrangell, allowing them to receive settlement land and compensation. The Act allows Native residents of Haines, Ketchikan, Petersburg, Tenakee, and Wrangell, Alaska to form Urban Corporations under the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act, without affecting existing entitlements to land. The Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act allows Native residents of Haines, Ketchikan, Petersburg, Tenakee, and Wrangell to form Urban Corporations, with provisions for enrollment and shares in the respective Urban Corporations. The Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act allows Natives in Southeast Alaska to form Urban Corporations. Natives inheriting shares from a decedent Native can receive the same number of shares in the Urban Corporation as inherited. This does not affect entitlement to land. The subsection does not affect entitlement to land of any Regional Corporation under specific sections. SEC. 5. DISTRIBUTION RIGHTS. Section 7 of the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act is amended to address the distribution of corporate funds and other net income among Native villages and shareholders in Urban Corporations. The Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act is amended to address the distribution of corporate funds and net income among Native villages and shareholders in Urban Corporations. The amendments clarify the eligibility of Native Village shareholders to receive distributions and specify that the Act will not affect revenue distribution ratios or settlement agreements among Native Corporations. SEC. 6. COMPENSATION. The Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act is amended to establish Urban Corporations for Haines, Ketchikan, Petersburg, Tenakee, and Wrangell. The Urban Corporations for Haines, Ketchikan, Petersburg, Tenakee, and Wrangell will receive compensation in the form of 1 township of land (23,040 acres) each, along with other appropriate compensation, as outlined in the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act. The Urban Corporations of Haines, Ketchikan, Petersburg, Tenakee, and Wrangell will receive compensation in the form of land with commercial, subsistence, and cultural sites, hydroelectric sites, tideland, surplus Federal property, and eco-tourism sites. The selected land will be contiguous and compact. The land selected pursuant to this section shall be subject to valid existing rights and provisions of section 14(g), including leases, contracts, permits, rights-of-way, and easements. The Secretary will offer $650,000 for capital expenses related to corporate organization and development, including identifying forest and land parcels. The Secretary will offer compensation for various activities including identification of forest and land parcels, conveyance requests, land valuations, corporation incorporation, shareholder enrollment, stock issuance, and seed capital for resource development. Additionally, the Secretary may offer grants and loan guarantees for planning and development purposes. The Urban Corporations under the Act may receive additional financial compensation allocated based on the number of shareholders. They must accept or reject the offer within one year, providing proper resolution to the Secretary. Urban Corporation must provide a certified corporate resolution stating the majority shareholder vote on the Secretary's offer. If the offer is rejected, the Secretary will revise it in consultation with Urban Corporation and the Regional Corporation for Southeast Alaska. Urban Corporation then has 180 days to accept or reject the revised offer. Within 180 days of approval, Urban Corporation must withdraw and convey land and title as per the Secretary's offer. The Secretary shall withdraw the land, convey surface estate to Urban Corporation, and subsurface estate to Regional Corporation for Southeast Alaska. Roads, trails, facilities, leases, and appurtenances will be conveyed to Urban Corporations without compensation. Settlement Trust provisions apply to Urban Corporations of Haines. The Urban Corporations of Haines, Ketchikan, Petersburg, Tenakee, and Wrangell may establish a settlement trust to promote the health, education, and welfare of trust beneficiaries and preserve Native heritage and culture. Proceeds and income from the trust shall first support elders and minor children, then all other enrollees. Authorization of appropriations is granted to carry out this Act and its amendments.
